description.narrative: In an effort to address the challenges limiting effective Local Revenue Mobilisation, in 2021, the Local Government Finance commission finalized the development of a Local Revenue Mobilisation Strategy. It is expected that implementation of the strategy will contribute to enhanced local revenue mobilization and improved service delivery at the local government level. Furthermore, between 2015 to-date, Oxfam in Uganda, SEATINI-Uganda, Public Affairs Centre-Uganda (PAC-U) and Advocates for Research in Development-Uganda (ARID) have worked with Local Government officials in Acholi and West Nile regions as well as the Teso Sub region to build the capacity of Local Governments officials to improve Local Government systems, for improved collection, allocation and utilisation of revenue. The partners have also created awareness among citizens and the communities on the need for them to pay their taxes, influence allocation of revenue and further demand for accountability on how the collected revenueis utilised. Efforts have also previously been directed towards advocacy for adoption of policies that create a conducive environment for Local Revenue Mobilisation. During the year 2021, Oxfam Uganda inpartnership with SEATINI Uganda, PAC-U, and ARID-Uganda implemented a Bill and Melinda Gates funded project titled: “Enhancing Equitable Subnational Revenue Mobilization in Gulu, and Soroti cities. As part of this project partners were able to develop and launch Local Revenue Enhancement Plans (LREPs) for the two cities. The Local Revenue Enhancement plans are part of the process to ensure that the newly created cities are able to improve their revenue collections in order to ably finance the provision of services for the people. Therefore buildingon these interventions, in this new project, Oxfam and project partners shall strengthen the capacity of targeted Local Governments to identify potential local revenue mobilisation sources, equitably mobilize, allocate and utilise local revenues from existing local/on sources for improved public service delivery, to reduce dependence on central government fiscal transfers and to strengthen the social contract to further empower citizens to appreciate the link between tax and development so as to play their role as taxpayers and further take up their right to demand for accountability from duty bearers for better social services.

participating-org.narrative:
The Southern and Eastern African Trade, Information and Negotiations Institute (SEATINI) Uganda is a regional non-governmental organisation founded in 1996 soon after the WTO Singapore Ministerial Conference. It happened when people realised that Africa in particular and Third World countries in general were marginalised in the World Trade Organisation's negotiations. SEATINI was formed to enhance the capacity in these negotiations of African trade officials and negotiators through technical assistance,and also through extending the trade debate to other stakeholders, especially civil society organisations, the media and parliaments. SEATINI also brings together African trade officials and negotiators, with a purpose of consolidating Africa's negotiating positions.
SEATINI was born when it was observed that: - African public policy in international forums is often determined ad hoc, and African governments are mostly takers, not makers, of international decisions that affect people's lives. Governments often sign international trade agreements without adequate information or analysis. Alternatively, the lack of a clear perception of their interests, they often resort to a simple negative posture rather than make commitments to agreements that mightbe of value to them; - the private sector is equally badly informed about the challenges of globalisation and the effect of the multilateral trading regime; - civil society understands the complexities of the international regime but it is often excludedfrom decision-making, both at home and in international forums.
Presently, the organisation has offices in Harare, Johannesburg, Kampala, Nairobi and Geneva. The Uganda office was established in 2001 and is fully registered with the Ministry of Internal Affairs. The country chapters are semi-autonomous with the country director responsible for reporting to the regional director in Zimbabwe. SEATINI has one board for the whole organisation.
ON THE FINANCE FOR DEVELOPMENT PROJECT: SEATINI Uganda is leading the implementation of Tax Justice interventions in Uganda at national level. This is aimed at influencing fair tax policy reform in Uganda at national level and closely works with other national and subnational level F4D partners.
